metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: Node.js MongoDB Find
In MongoDB we use the find and findOne methods to find data in a collection.
content.html: In MongoDB we use the find and findOne methods to find data in a collection.

content.text: Just like the SELECT statement is used to find data in a table in a MySQL database.
content.html: Just like the SELECT statement is used to find data in a table in a MySQL database.

content.text: Find One
To select data from a collection in MongoDB, we can use the findOne() method.
content.html: To select data from a collection in MongoDB, we can use the findOne() method.

content.text: The findOne() method returns the first occurrence in the selection.
content.html: The findOne() method returns the first occurrence in the selection.

content.text: The first parameter of the findOne() method is a query object. In this example we use an empty query object, which selects all documents in a collection (but returns only the first document).
content.html: The first parameter of the findOne() method is a query object. In this example we use an empty query object, which selects all documents in a collection (but returns only the first document).

content.code_html:
var MongoClient = require('mongodb').MongoClient;
var url = "mongodb://localhost:27017/";

MongoClient.connect(url, function(err, db) {
  if (err) throw err;
  var dbo = db.db("mydb");
  dbo.collection("customers").findOne({}, function(err, result) {
    if (err) throw err;
    console.log(result.name);
    db.close();
  });
});

content.text: Save the code above in a file called "demo_mongodb_findone.js" and run the file:
content.html: Save the code above in a file called "demo_mongodb_findone.js" and run the file:

content.code_html: C:\Users\Your Name>node demo_mongodb_findone.js

content.text: Which will give you this result:
content.html: Which will give you this result:

content.text: Find All
To select data from a table in MongoDB, we can also use the find() method.
content.html: To select data from a table in MongoDB, we can also use the find() method.

content.text: The find() method returns all occurrences in the selection.
content.html: The find() method returns all occurrences in the selection.

content.text: The first parameter of the find() method is a query object. In this example we use an empty query object, which selects all documents in the collection.
content.html: The first parameter of the find() method is a query object. In this example we use an empty query object, which selects all documents in the collection.

content.text: No parameters in the find() method gives you the same result as SELECT * in MySQL.
content.html: No parameters in the find() method gives you the same result as SELECT * in MySQL.

content.code_html:
var MongoClient = require('mongodb').MongoClient;
var url = "mongodb://localhost:27017/";

MongoClient.connect(url, function(err, db) {
  if (err) throw err;
  var dbo = db.db("mydb");
  dbo.collection("customers").find({}).toArray(function(err, result) {
    if (err) throw err;
    console.log(result);
    db.close();
  });
});

content.text: Save the code above in a file called "demo_mongodb_find.js" and run the file:
content.html: Save the code above in a file called "demo_mongodb_find.js" and run the file:

content.code_html: C:\Users\Your Name>node demo_mongodb_find.js

content.text: Which will give you this result:
content.html: Which will give you this result:

content.text: Find Some
The second parameter of the find() method is the projection object that describes which fields to include in the result.
content.html: The second parameter of the find() method is the projection object that describes which fields to include in the result.

content.text: This parameter is optional, and if omitted, all fields will be included in the result.
content.html: This parameter is optional, and if omitted, all fields will be included in the result.

content.code_html:
var MongoClient = require('mongodb').MongoClient;
var url = "mongodb://localhost:27017/";

MongoClient.connect(url, function(err, db) {
  if (err) throw err;
  var dbo = db.db("mydb");
  dbo.collection("customers").find({}, { projection: { _id: 0, name: 1, address: 1 } }).toArray(function(err, result) {
    if (err) throw err;
    console.log(result);
    db.close();
  });
});

content.text: Save the code above in a file called "demo_mongodb_find_fields.js" and run the file:
content.html: Save the code above in a file called "demo_mongodb_find_fields.js" and run the file:

content.code_html: C:\Users\Your Name>node demo_mongodb_find_fields.js

content.text: Which will give you this result:
content.html: Which will give you this result:

content.text: You are not allowed to specify both 0 and 1 values in the same object (except if one of the fields is the _id field). If you specify a field with the value 0, all other fields get the value 1, and vice versa:
content.html: You are not allowed to specify both 0 and 1 values in the same object (except if one of the fields is the _id field). If you specify a field with the value 0, all other fields get the value 1, and vice versa:

content.code_html:
var MongoClient = require('mongodb').MongoClient;
var url = "mongodb://localhost:27017/";

MongoClient.connect(url, function(err, db) {
  if (err) throw err;
  var dbo = db.db("mydb");
  dbo.collection("customers").find({}, { projection: { address: 0 } }).toArray(function(err, result) {
    if (err) throw err;
    console.log(result);
    db.close();
  });
});

content.text: To exclude the _id field, you must set its value to 0:
content.html: To exclude the _id field, you must set its value to 0:

content.code_html:
var MongoClient = require('mongodb').MongoClient;
var url = "mongodb://localhost:27017/";

MongoClient.connect(url, function(err, db) {
  if (err) throw err;
  var dbo = db.db("mydb");
  dbo.collection("customers").find({}, { projection: { _id: 0, name: 1 } }).toArray(function(err, result) {
    if (err) throw err;
    console.log(result);
    db.close();
  });
});

var MongoClient = require('mongodb').MongoClient;
var url = "mongodb://localhost:27017/";

MongoClient.connect(url, function(err, db) {
  if (err) throw err;
  var dbo = db.db("mydb");
  dbo.collection("customers").find({}, { projection: { _id: 0 } }).toArray(function(err, result) {
    if (err) throw err;
    console.log(result);
    db.close();
  });
});

var MongoClient = require('mongodb').MongoClient;
var url = "mongodb://localhost:27017/";

MongoClient.connect(url, function(err, db) {
  if (err) throw err;
  var dbo = db.db("mydb");
  dbo.collection("customers").find({}, { projection: { name: 1, address: 0 } }).toArray(function(err, result) {
    if (err) throw err;
    console.log(result);
    db.close();
  });
});

content.text: The Result Object
As you can see from the result of the example above, the result can be converted into an array containing each document as an object.
content.html: As you can see from the result of the example above, the result can be converted into an array containing each document as an object.

content.text: To return e.g. the address of the third document, just refer to the third array object's address property:
content.html: To return e.g. the address of the third document, just refer to the third array object's address property:
